text.p: - Having supported the draft 1997 budget, the communists in the State Duma, the lower house of Russian parliament, have lost the moral right to call themselves an opposition.
- Credit cards for poor people who have not seen cash for months, may be introduced in Kuzbass, the Siberian coal region plagued with wages arrears.
- Boris Yeltsin's younger daughter Tatyana Dyachenko is likely to be given a position of presidential aide which will formalise her power in the Kremlin.
- The law on weapons signed by President Yeltsin yesterday will not change much in Russia's life.

- Dramatic disagreements between Russia and NATO on the Alliance's eastwards expansion make it necessary to work out a special wide scale agreement which may become a basis for a European security system.
- President Yeltsin is taking four or five hour walks in the Zavidovo residence and fewer doctors are watching after him, presidential press-secretary Sergei Yastrzhembsky says.
- The conditions put forward by the communist opposition before approving the 1997 budget in the State Duma, are unlikely to be met.
- Despite a lot of problems the Audit Department of the Russian finance ministry is trying to track how money allocated for Chechnya from the federal budget had been spent.
